summary: A compilation of blog posts from DealBreaker.com from July to September 2006, critiquing media coverage (especially the New York Times) of the Jeffrey Epstein case, detailing allegations against him, his legal defense, political donations being returned, and his connections to powerful figures. It highlights the early public narrative and skepticism around the prosecution.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the sex scandal, accused of soliciting prostitution and sexual misconduct with underage girls. His legal team is mounting a defense and he is a major political donor.

persons.name: John Carney
persons.context: Primary author of the blog posts, providing commentary and reporting on the Epstein case and media coverage.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Part of Epstein's legal team, argued to prosecutors that the accusers were not credible due to drug use and lying.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: Palm Beach prosecutor criticized for perceived preferential treatment of Epstein and for previously pursuing Rush Limbaugh.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.context: Led the police investigation into Epstein; his pursuit of the case was attacked by Epstein's lawyers.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Linked to Epstein as a social companion; daughter of media mogul Robert Maxwell.

persons.name: Les Wexner
persons.role: CEO of Limited Brands, Epstein's client
persons.context: Epstein's only confirmed client; founder of The Limited (Victoria's Secret). Connection sparked speculation about his CFO's resignation.

persons.name: Bill Richardson
persons.context: New Mexico politician who received campaign donations from Epstein and donated them to charity.

persons.name: Eliot Spitzer
persons.context: Returned a $50,000 campaign contribution from Epstein.

persons.name: Greg Solano
persons.context: Received $2,000 from Epstein for his campaign; stated he had spent the money and was in debt.

persons.name: Jim Baca
persons.context: Received $10,000 from Epstein and considered returning it or donating to charity.

persons.name: Gary King
persons.context: Received $15,000 from Epstein and planned to 'dump' the tainted money.

persons.name: Ken Stevens
persons.context: Resigned after two months; blog speculates a possible connection to discomfort over Wexner's ties to Epstein.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's lawyer who claimed Epstein insisted visitors be over 18.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Part of Epstein's legal 'army' as mentioned in the blog.

persons.name: Dan Klores
persons.context: New York publicist working for Epstein's camp.

persons.name: Abby Goodnough
persons.context: Wrote the NYT story on Epstein that is critiqued in the blog.

persons.name: Bill O'Reilly
persons.context: Criticized prosecutor Barry Krischer for alleged political bias in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Rush Limbaugh
persons.context: Referenced as someone prosecutor Krischer previously pursued on drug charges, contrasted with Epstein case.

persons.name: Steven Hoffenberg
persons.context: Epstein's mentor who was later imprisoned for running a Ponzi scheme.

persons.name: Larry Summers
persons.context: Listed among Epstein's powerful friends.

persons.name: Mort Zuckerman
persons.context: Listed among Epstein's powerful friends.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Listed among Epstein's powerful friends.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Quoted in a past profile saying Epstein liked 'beautiful women... on the younger side'.

persons.name: John Mack
persons.context: Appeared on a document signed by Epstein as trustee, connecting DealBreaker topics.

persons.name: Stephen Hawking
persons.context: Attended a physics symposium in St. Thomas organized by Epstein.

persons.name: Gerardus 't Hooft
persons.context: Attended a physics symposium organized by Epstein.

persons.name: David Gross
persons.context: Attended a physics symposium organized by Epstein.

persons.name: Frank Wilczek
persons.context: Attended a physics symposium organized by Epstein.

persons.name: Joe Francis
persons.context: His theory linking sexual appetite to business success is mentioned in relation to Epstein.

persons.name: Elizabeth Spiers
persons.context: Co-author of one blog post about an anonymous account of an Epstein party.

persons.name: Mark Green
persons.context: Returned a $10,000 campaign donation from Epstein.

connections.description: Dershowitz is part of Epstein's legal defense team, arguing to prosecutors about the credibility of accusers.
Long linked socially; Maxwell is described as a companion.
Wexner is Epstein's only confirmed client; Epstein served as trustee for the Wexner Children's Trust II.
Reiter, as Police Chief, led the investigation against Epstein; Epstein's lawyers attacked Reiter's character.
Krischer is the state attorney prosecuting (or perceived as lenient toward) Epstein; criticized for handling of the case.
Epstein made significant campaign donations to Richardson, who later donated them to charity.
Epstein donated to Spitzer's campaign; Spitzer returned the contribution.
Hoffenberg was Epstein's mentor early in his career.
Stevens was CFO of Wexner's company, Limited Brands; his resignation sparked speculation linked to Epstein.
Both signed the same credit agreement amendment for Reliant Pharmaceuticals, connecting their professional circles.

events.title: NYT Publishes Epstein Story
events.description: The New York Times publishes a story titled 'Questions of Preferential Treatment Are Raised in Sex Case Against Money Manager', which the blog criticizes for its focus.

events.title: Spitzer Returns Epstein Donation
events.description: Eliot Spitzer returns a $50,000 campaign contribution from Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI Considers Epstein Probe
events.description: Reports surface that the FBI is considering a federal investigation into Epstein's alleged sex crimes, following local police frustration.

events.title: Terrorist Security Disruption
events.description: Blog jokingly notes enhanced airport security would disrupt travel plans, but notes Epstein's private jet avoids such issues.

events.title: Allegations of Epstein Orgy Parties
events.description: Anonymous blog comment alleges Epstein hosted parties with Nobel laureates and nude Eastern European girls leading to orgies.

events.title: Epstein's Teaching History Revealed
events.description: Blog notes Epstein taught math and physics at the Dalton School from 1973-1975, raising questions about his long-term behavior.

events.title: Allegation of Sex Slave
events.description: Gawker reports a police document alleges Epstein bragged about purchasing a woman from her family in Yugoslavia to be his sex slave.

keyFacts: The New York Times was heavily criticized for delayed and oddly framed coverage of the Epstein case, focusing on 'preferential treatment' rather than the allegations themselves.
Epstein's legal defense strategy involved attacking the credibility of the accusers as 'liars, thieves, and drug-users' and smearing law enforcement, including Police Chief Michael Reiter.
Multiple politicians, including Governor Bill Richardson and candidate Eliot Spitzer, returned or donated to charity campaign contributions received from Jeffrey Epstein.
The FBI was reportedly considering a federal investigation into Epstein's activities as of August 2006, due to local police frustration with the state prosecution.
Epstein was connected to powerful figures including Les Wexner (his only confirmed client), scientists like Stephen Hawking, and politicians like Bill Clinton.
